Check out http://playdoh.readthedocs.org/en/latest/packages.html about installing to vendor-local.

Thanks for taking the time! A fresh pair of eyes helps. 

I can't merge it as is as there are a couple of things I don't agree with. 

To begin with, we need to find a common way for settings/dev.py and settings/local.py-dist to co-exist. We can't have both. It's repeated code. 
I think what I would like to see, is local.py-dist to continue to be geared towards IT deployment and instead use documentation to gear it towards eager coders. E.g. 

> Now run `cp airmozilla/settings/local.py-dist airmozilla/settings/local.py` and now start editing airmozilla/settings/local.py for your development needs. You might want to go in and set up the `DATABASES` to match your local MySQL. And to make error reporting easier, set things in debug mode by editing some lines so it says::
>   DEBUG = DEBUG_TEMPLATE = True

I know there's some sort of metric of contributions where people get a reward for forking a repo. However, I think it'll be a smoother ride if you don't start with that. 

Documentation that lumps Getting Started with Submit Your First Pull Request is more trouble to a newbie mind.

This bug originally brought this up: Please weigh in there too if you have a chance:
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=823162
Actually, now I see. The bug says the same thing as you suggest.

FYI, I later changed the word "video" to "event" which makes us more future compatible with events that are only audio. Something there already exists a couple of. 
https://github.com/mozilla/airmozilla/commit/a44cbae21a3185b60d4c5ea17a63d872d11532c2

Hi Nate,

That's very good feedback but the truth is, I don't use vagrant. Not for Air Mozilla or for any other project so I think it's going to be hard to maintain it. 

Luke was onto something with the idea of stop calling it "settings/local.py" and instead using "settings/dev.py" OR "settings/prod.py" which means so much more. That might be a good do-able solution for this issue.

Another common problem is that caching doesn't work. This is most commonly the problem when you have `django.core.cache.backends.memcached.MemcachedCache` in your settings/local.py for the `CACHES` setting. ...but don't have a working memcache server running on your laptop. If that's the case, there are two options:
1) install and run memcache on port `:11211` (which is the default port)
2) change the `CACHES` setting to look like this:

```
CACHES = {
    'default': {
        'BACKEND': 'django.core.cache.backends.locmem.LocMemCache',
        'LOCATION': 'crashstats'
    }
}
```

One very good way to testing if caching works is to do this:

```
$ ./manage.py shell
>>> from django.core.cache import cache
>>> cache.set('foo', 'bar', 60)
```

exit and immediately start the shell again:

```
$ ./manage.py shell
>>> from django.core.cache import cache
>>> assert cache.get('foo') == 'bar'
```

Actually, we don't need a test for this. If we were to write a test we'd effectively be testing that Django works. But we have to trust that it does. 
Sometimes it's worth writing a test for something that where the actual code change is just a "flip-switch" but this I don't think is particularly interesting.

For example, to run a specific file:

```
./manage.py test -s -x airmozilla/manage/tests/test_forms.py
```

To run a specific test case class in a file:

```
./manage.py test -s -x airmozilla/manage/tests/test_forms.py:SomeTestCaseClass
```

or to run a specific test:

```
./manage.py test -s -x airmozilla/manage/tests/test_forms.py:SomeTestCaseClass.test_some_function
```

The `-s` makes it so that any print statements aren't swallowed if tests pass. The `-x` means it bails as soon as 1 test fails.

I'd recommend against these short ones. It works today when you have the models.py file. But in five years when someone writes a migration script for the mysql database dump they won't know what `I` and `S` means. 

Instead I suggest you do this:

``` python
class MyModel:
    INITIATED = 'initiated'
    SCHEDULED = 'scheduled'
    STATUS_CHOICES = (
        (INITIATED, 'Initiated'),
        (SCHEDULED, 'Scheduled'),
    )
   status = models.CharField(max_length=20, choices=STATUS_CHOICES, default=INITIATED)
```

Then you can do cool things like this later:

``` python
events = Event.objects.filter(status=Event.SCHEDULED)
```

Lastly, depending on how many more status choices you envision you might consider naming the constants something like this instead: `STATUS_SCHEDULED`, `STATUS_INITIATED`.

` here. We have less space in the sidebar so I think it's nice that all linebreaks collapse into one paragraph. Now, the `words=10` is really scary too. What if you have something like this: ``` one two three four five six seven eight nine ten eleven twelve thirteen. ``` If you chop that at 10 words you'll get ``` one two three four five six seven eight nine ten... ``` which means you're exposing invalid HTML. {{ short_desc(live, 10, remove_html=True) }} ``` You're going to need to write lots of tests but I'm happy to help you.

There's usually a space between selector if they're about quite different things. E.g. the line above about `p.founds-tags, ...` is a about tags. So it should be a space between that an `.event-channels`. 

Also, the format is:

```
[SELECTORS][SPACE]{[SPACE][KEY]:[SPACE][VALUE];[SPACE]}
```

So it should technically be:

``` css
.event-channels { padding-left: 20px; }
```

Ideally we should be using this format everywhere:

``` css
.event-channels {
    padding-left: 20px;
}
```

but the one-liner format has unfortunately slipped in in many places over the years. 

Perhaps a bug worth working on to 1) document that standard and 2) a clean-up for all CSS that uses one-liners. 
Interested?

Can you add one more thing?
Can you add a `title` tag like this: `title="Click to go to the {{ channel.name }} channel"`
Also, can you please use the `{{ channel.name }}` notation. There might be other places where we use `{{channel.name}}` but we should try to stick to the standard of using spaces consistently.

That means that you get an empty `
  • ` if the if statement is false. Shouldn't the `
  • ` and `
    • ` be inside the if statement.

First of all we can't guarantee that there's just 1 VidlySubmission for this event. There's a reasonably big chance that there might be more than one which is the case when they have to re-submit a new video to Vid.ly due to some encoding problems or something. Also, there's actually a possibility that an event has a Vid.ly template but 0 VidlySubmissions. The only reasonable case I can think of is if someone has cloned an event and manually copied the vidly tag over to the new event. Or perhaps they made the vidly submission manually with some other tool. 

I think the best solution would be to assume that HD is NOT available. That's because I think 404 Page Not Found is more horrible than that a user has to watch the downloaded SD version.

Also, when you do that query on `VidlySubmission.objects.` you should also use the tag. E.g. `event=event, tag=context['vidly_tag'])`. 

So I think the ideal solution would be to use a loop. Like this:

``` python
hd = False  # default
vidly_submissions = (
    VidlySubmission.objects
    .filter(event=event, tag=context['vidly_tag'])

)
for vidly_submission in vidly_submissions.order_by('-submission_time'):
    hd = vidly_submission['hd']
    break
```

That way it works if there are 0 or more than 1 VidlySubmissions (by filtering by `tag`) it's extremely unlikely to ever be more than 1 but even if there is we solve that by sorting by submission_time and breaking.

We need to change this variable name. That template `event.html` has a lot going on and it's best to stick to more descriptive variable names otherwise it might one day become hard to debug what's going on. Other things might be HD too, like the poster thumbnail for example. 
Perhaps it's as simple as calling it `vidly_hd` instead?
This line is not necessary. the `MyModel.objects.create()` does a save.
Can you change this to something like `https://s3.example.com/some/file.mov`
ditto
ditto

The next test `test_event_without_vidly_hd_download_links` is a bit repetitive. You could just carry on the first `test_event_with_vidly_hd_download_links` and after you've done these four `ok_(...)` tests, you just set 

```
vidly_submission.hd = False
vidly_submission.save()

response = self.client.get(url)
...
```
You might want to change `test_event_with_vidly_hd_download_links` to something more "generic" that works for both cases.

Having to do the SQL query is inevitable but it's excessive to have to turn it into and ORM object when all we ever need is the `hd` attribute of one item. 
We can fix that by instead doing:

``` python
for vidly_submission in vidly_submissions.values('hd'):
    hd = vidly_submission['hd']
    break
```

It might be premature optimization but it is after all something that gets called on every event on every request.

This file needs some cleaning up. Consistent spacing, same indentation and the last line needs to be a `\n`.

E.g.

``` python
>>> open('airmozilla/manage/static/manage/css/survey.css').read()[-1]
' '
>>> open('airmozilla/surveys/static/surveys/css/survey.css').read()[-1]
'\n'
```

That's why GitHub puts a little red stop and return icon here. 

What editor are you using? You should be able to configure it to automatically fix that on save.

In the model for Event, I specified the length of the slug to be the same as the length of the title, so the slug should always be ok (slugify just replaces characters).  I accidentally left this out on participants though.
also I guess if there's duplicates, some characters can be added, (monday-meeting-1398 for example), so maybe it would be safe to do slug field length = title field length + 10?
ok - ideally I'd like the two to be merged at the end, so I didn't worry about it.

is_active is preferred, I think - it's the active field on the user, is_authenticated just tells if a user is logged in.  is_active can be toggled by an admin to "remove" a user.  for us it probably doesn't matter very much though...

they want a way to "clear" profiles before they are visible publicly - i.e., add data about a presenter, email it to the presenter, have them approve it or request changes, and then publish it.  If the profile isn't cleared, no one should be able to see it.

This happens when you hit the cancel button on the form.  If you're "sure" you want to cancel, it's a submit/redirect.  If you're not sure, you stay on the form to continue editing or whatnot (i.e., you hit cancel by accident).

I think that a user couldn't be authenticated without being active, so the difference is usually unimportant.  The edge case that might come up is if you inactivate someone who's already authenticated.

I just could add the sencond event and check for that event in the same test, what you say?
Something has changed, now you have to execute: `docker build -t airmozilla .`

README.md says that you have to modify your `settings/local.py` to be able to connect with your database, why we can't do the same for docker?

The only way I see to feed  `settings/local.py` is to create a shell script that need to be executed before `docker build ...`
You can't execute that command with `~/airmozilla`, you need to write the full path to your local folder
do `docker rm airmozilla`
My mistake do `docker stop web` then `docker rm web` and try again

I remember this being somewhat funky in the current infastructure so I made a little test with `pdb` to make sure that this is true and found out that event isn't always attached to the instance so replacing the `event_id` form property with `self.instance.event` is not possible.


Nope still no dice.

I'm hesitant to change this since I think most of the functionality so far is reliant on this being an event id and not a full fledged event. If you are adamant about it I can dive into it and maybe it's not as bad as I'm imagining it but if this is a ignorable nitpick I'd want to leave as is.

Sorry for the late answer, I've been quite busy :)

Looking at this again I've got to say that I still think that this should be `event_id`. In my opinion it's not equivalent of calling a `description_string` since this variable is the id of a event and not the event itself and calling it `event` would be wrong. The equivalent would be calling it `event_int` which would be not good either. To further illustrate my point I think that we'll run into some problems with naming variables when in situations like such:

``` python
def edit_event(request, event):  # Event here is the id of the event not the actual event.
    actual_event = Event.objects.get(id=event)
    ...
```

To me this feels very unreadable and I would strongly prefer this form:

``` python
def edit_event(request, event_id):
    event = Event.objects.get(id=event_id)
    ...
```
